questions.text: A patient hailing from an area infested with mosquitoes presents with fever, chills, and myalgias. WBC count was 4000 cells/cu.mm, RBC was normal, and platelets were 90000 cells/cu.mm. He also had a maculopapular rash. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a patient hailing from a mosquito-infested area with fever and decreased platelet counts is diagnostic of dengue. 

Symptoms of severe dengue are headache, myalgias, retroorbital pain, end-organ damage, pleural & ascitic effusions and thrombocytopenia (<100,000/ uL). Complications include mild hepatic injury, seizures, arrythmias and acute kidney injury.

Diagnosis is made by NS1 antigen detection and IgM antibody assays. Treatment includes crystalloid infusion in mild cases and colloid infusion in severe cases, oxygen administration and close monitoring.

Dengue is classified into dengue with or without warning signs and severe dengue. Dengue is to be suspected when a high fever (40°C/104°F) is accompanied by any two of the following symptoms during the febrile phase (2-7 days) which include severe headache, retro-orbital pain, arthralgia or myalgia, nausea, vomiting and maculopapular rash.

Warning signs in dengue are:

  • severe abdominal pain
  • persistent vomiting
  • tachypnea
  • bleeding gums or nose 
  • fatigue
  • restlessness
  • hepatomegaly
  • malena or hematemesis

questions.text: Anuj, a school-going kid has been brought to the pediatric OPD by his mother with complaints of fever for 3 weeks. She says her son has been skipping school because of the fever but in the evening he gets better and plays with his siblings. She also noticed a rash that appears along with fever and disappears spontaneously. He has a history of joint pain on and off since pre-school. On examination, generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are noted along with an evanescent erythematous rash on the trunk. Which of the following characteristically defines the fever associated with this child's condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has clinical features of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA), which is associated with quotidian fever. Quotidian fever - fever that rises to 39°C (102.2°F) once a day and returns to 37°C (98.6°F) between fever peaks

Systemic JIA is characterized by a fever of at least 2 weeks and Arthritis in 1 or more joints + at least one of 

  1. Evanescent erythematous rash that is non-pruritic and migratory with lesions lasting<1 hr.
  2. Prominent visceral involvement, including hepatosplenomegaly
  3. Generalized lymphadenopathy
  4. Serositis

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is a patient with fever unlikely to have clubbing?
questions.solution:
Rheumatic fever is associated with fever but not clubbing while all the other conditions listed are known to be associated with clubbing.

Clubbing is a clinical finding characterized by selective bulbous enlargement of the distal segments of the fingers and toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue, especially on the dorsal surface.

Causes of clubbing:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma, asbestosis
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Tuberculosis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
  • Gastrointestinal
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Patent ductus arteriosus (causes differential clubbing)
    • Aortic aneurysm 
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
    • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • Neurological
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)
  • Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is an associated feature in clubbing seen due to primary or metastatic lung disease, mesothelioma, bronchiectasis, and hepatic cirrhosis. It can be diagnosed using a bone radiograph or MRI.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing:

Schamroth sign: This sign is elicited by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, whereas in clubbed fingers, this diamond-shaped window is obliterated. 

Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: This is defined by the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, the profile angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.

questions.text: A 5 year old girl has 3 month history of joint pain and morning stiffness,  with swelling of knees and ankles. She also has eye pain and photophobia. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This given scenario is that of Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

It fulfills the criteria for JIA,which is -

  • Age of onset: <16 yr
  • Duration of disease: At least more than or equal to 6 weeks
  • Arthritis in at least 1 joint
  • Exclusion of other forms of juvenile arthritis.

JIA is an autoimmune disease that is associated with both humoral and cell mediated immunity.

questions.text:
In which of the following conditions may Faget's sign be noted?
  1. Dengue
  2. Typhoid
  3. Brucellosis
  4. Leptospirosis
  5. Malaria
questions.solution:
Relative bradycardia/Faget’s sign is seen when patients have a lower heart rate than might be expected for a given body temperature.

It can be seen in all of the above conditions.

The body temperature is often considered an independent determinant of heart rate. It is estimated that for every centigrade rise in temperature, the heart rate increases approximately by 10 bpm.

Infectious organism causing relative bradycardia include: 

  • Salmonella typhi (typhoid/enteric fever)
  • Francisella tularensis
  • Brucella spp.
  • Coxiella burnetii (Q fever)
  • Leptospira interrogans (leptospirosis)
  • Legionella pneumophila
  • Rickettsia spp.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi (scrub typhus)
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • Plasmodium spp. (malaria)

Viruses/viral infections:

  • Yellow fever virus
  • Dengue virus
  • Viral hemorrhagic fevers - Early in course of Marburg and Ebola
  • Viral myocarditis

Noninfectious causes include:

  • Drug fever 
  • Beta-blocker use 
  • Central nervous system lesions
  • Malignant lymphoma
  • Factitious fever

questions.text: A 27 year old P1L1 in the post-natal ward who delivered three days prior, has a temperature of 39°C on two occasions 24 hours apart. Which of the following points in her history would identify the most important risk factor for her fever?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of puerperal fever. The route of delivery, i.e., whether vaginal or caeserean, is the single biggest risk factor for development of genital tract infection, which is the most common cause of puerperal fever.

Puerperal fever is defined as a temperature of >38°C recorded on 2 separate occasions 24 hours apart within the first 10 days following delivery. The most common cause of puerperal fever is genital tract infection. Women who have delivered by caesarean section carry a significantly higher risk of developing infection as compared to those who have a normal vaginal delivery. Infection of the genital tract has also been termed puerperal sepsis and includes endometritis, endo-myometritis, and endo-parametritis, and a combination of all is called pelvic cellulitis. However, routine use of antibiotic prophylaxis has now reduced the incidence of puerperal fever following caesarean delivery.

The period following childbirth, from the time of the delivery of the placenta, is called puerperium. It is further subdivided into immediate - first 24 hours, early - first 7 days, and remote - 7 days to 6 weeks.

A number of physiological changes take place during the puerperal period which include the involution of the uterus, discharge of lochia and onset of lactation. The presence of fever on the 3rd day after delivery which lasts for 24 hours may occur due to breast engorgement is known as breast fever, which is self-limiting.

Other causes of puerperal fever include:

  • urinary tract infection
  • breast infection (abscess/mastitis)
  • pelvic infection including septic pelvic thrombophlebitis
  • respiratory infections

questions.text: In which of the following patients with fever, would a detailed family history lead directly to the diagnosis?

choices.text: 32-year-old female who is febrile after receiving a blood transfusion
43-year-old male with periodic fever and recently diagnosed amyloidosis
23-year-old female with fever and eosinophilia and lymphadenopathy
18-year-old male with fever, joint pains and elevated CRP

questions.solution:
A positive family history of similar complaints in other individuals in the family of a patient with recurrent fever associated with the later diagnosis of amyloidosis would favor the diagnosis of Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF).

Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF) is an autosomal recessive inherited auto-inflammatory condition that occurs due to a defect in the FMF gene that encodes the protein pyrin. It was first recognised in the population living close to the Mediterranean Sea, hence the name, but has also been identified in other regions. Pyrin activity leads to inflammasome activation that results in signs of acute attacks of inflammation in the patient such as recurrent fever, arthritis, peritonitis and pleuritis, with attacks lasting between 24-72 hours. Factors like exercise, emotional stress and pregnancy may act as triggers for the attacks.

AA Amyloidosis is a known common complication of FMF, especially in patients with a homozygous genotype. Patients are treated with daily oral colchicine which prevents attacks and also reduces the risk of developing systemic amyloidosis.

Other options:

Option A: A patient with a febrile reaction to a blood transfusion may have a positive family history of immune-mediated diseases (eg. IgA deficiency) but a family history alone would be insufficient to form a diagnosis before ruling out several other possibilities. A detailed past history of similar occurrences or haematological diseases would be more relevant in such a patient.

Option C: A patient with fever, eosinophilia and lymphadenopathy should rather have a detailed medication history to rule out drug-induced fevers like DRESS syndrome and travel history to rule out parasitic infections.

Option D: A young male with fever, joint pains and elevated CRP should raise the differential of rheumatic fever which could be elicited with a past history of recent sore throat. The patient should also be evaluated for systemic autoimmune illnesses (eg. Still's disease).

questions.text:
What is the typical sequence of events that take place to result in fever?
  1. Release of pyrogens in circulation
  2. Increase in PGE2 in organum vasculosum
  3. Stimulation of EP3 receptors on glial cells
  4. Release of cAMP
  5. Elevation of hypothalamic set-point
questions.solution:
Fever occurs due to an elevation in the hypothalamic set-point which acts as the thermoregulator of the body.

In the setting of an infectious cause, pyrogens are released by the causative organism in the form of toxins or due to the activation of pyroegenic cytokines due to the presence of a foreign organism.

↓

This causes the synthesis of PGE2, whose levels are elevated in the organum vasculosum - a network of capillaries surrounding the hypothalamic regulatory centres: the preoptic anterior hypothalamus and the posterior hypothalamus.

↓

Increased PGE2 triggers the EP3 prostaglandin receptors in the glial cells of the brain

↓

release of cAMP from glial cells 

↓

 elevation of hypothalamic set-point

↓

Fever

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely in a patient presenting with complaints of fever and night sweats?
questions.solution:
Fever with night sweats is unlikely in a patient with a urinary tract infection(UTI).

Fever with night sweats is a common presentation in chronic conditions rather than acute conditions. UTI generally has an acute presentation with patients complaining of high-grade fever associated with voiding symptoms such as burning micturition, haematuria, and other renal symptoms such as flank pain or abdominal pain.

Other options:

Option B: Evening rise of temperature and night sweats is a common presentation in tuberculosis. This is believed to be due to the diurnal variation in cortisol secretion which is reduced in the evening.

Option C: Night sweats is one of the 'B' symptoms associated with lymphomas.

Option D: Peri- and post-menopausal women typically complain of hot-flashes and night sweats.

questions.text: Which of the following patterns of fever is characteristic of Hodgkin's lymphoma?

choices.text: Temperature remains elevated above normal, without touching the baseline, and the degree of fluctuation is <0.6 °C
Fever lasts for 3–10 days, followed by an afebrile period of 3–10 days
Temperature remains elevated above normal, without touching the baseline, and the degree of fluctuation is >0.6 °C
Acute fever followed by a remission lasting for 1–2 days; then, the fever reappears and lasts for 1-2 days

questions.solution:
Hodgkin's lymphoma and other lymphomas are typically associated with Pel-Ebstein fever, where the patient has fever lasting for 3–10 days, followed by an afebrile period of 3–10 days. 

Other specific patterns of fever include:

Continuous fever is characterized by the temperature remaining elevated, without touching the baseline, and the fluctuation not exceeding 0.6°C. This type of fever is seen in cases of lobar pneumonia, infective endocarditis, enteric fever, etc. (Option A)

Remittent fever is characterized by temperature fluctuations exceeding 0.6°C, but without touching the baseline. (Option C)

Relapsing fever is characterized by several days of fever, followed by several days of an afebrile period, after which the cycle repeats (e.g. Borrelia, Leptospirosis)

Tertian fever occurs on the first and third days. (e.g. infection with Plasmodium vivax, Plasmodium ovale, and Plasmodium falciparum)

Quartan fever occurs on the first and fourth days. (e.g. Plasmodium malariae infection)

Saddleback fever characterized by acute fever followed by a remission lasting for 1–2 days; then fever reappears and lasts for 1-2 days. This type of fever is typicall seen in dengue. (Option D)

questions.text: A patient started on anticonvulsants 6 weeks ago presenting with a temperature of 38°C and a generalised rash is suspected to have a drug-induced fever. Which of the following drugs is unlikely to have caused this?
questions.solution:
Drug-induced fever, is unlikely to be caused by levetiracetam.

The other options mentioned, i.e., carbamazepine, lamotrigine and phenytoin are all aromatic anticonvulsants which are known to be associated with adverse events like drug-fever and DRESS syndrome. Levetiracetam is a non-aromatic anticonvulsant.

Drugs are common causes of fever either due to side effects of the drug itself or due to an immune reaction to the drug. Drug-fever is also a differential in patients with fever of unknown origin and is to be ruled out before performing advanced investigations.

DRESS stands for Drug Rash with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms. Patients present with a fever and generalised rash, but since in some cases there is no eosinophilia, the term Drug Induced Hypersensitivity Syndrome (DIHS) may be preferred. Commonly implicated medications include:

  • Antiepileptics – carbamazepine, phenytoin, lamotrigine
  • Antibiotics – vancomycin, amoxicillin, minocycline, piperacillin-tazobactam
  • Sulpha drugs – sulphasalazine, dapsone, sulphadiazine
  • Furosemide
  • Omeprazole
  • Ibuprofen 

Patients with DRESS will recover fully, following withdrawal of the culprit drug and supportive management of the acute episode.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is antipyretics not indicated?
questions.solution:
Antipyretics are not indicated in the management of heat stroke or other environmentally induced hyperthermic states as antipyretics act at the hypothalamic thermoregulatory level. They may also exacerbate the complications (acute kidney injury, hepatic failure, DIC).

Heat stroke is of 2 types:

  • Exertion-induced heat stroke (EHS) is seen in young, previously healthy people. It most commonly occurs in athletes, labourers, and military recruits working hard in a hot environment.
  • Sedentary/Classic/Epidemic heatstroke (CHS) is seen in elderly or infirm people during heat waves as their cardiovascular systems are unable to adapt to the stress of a hot environment to release sufficient heat. These patients are often compliant with prescribed medications that can impair tolerance to heat stress.

Patients usually present with a sudden collapse. The skin is dry, flushed, and hot. Sweating is absent in CHS but present in about 50% of cases of EHS. CNS dysfunction signs include delirium, coma, and convulsions. Other complications include rhabdomyolysis, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and multiorgan failure.

The key points in the management of heat stroke includes:

  • Rapid cooling: this could be by spraying the patient with cold water at 15°C; immersion cooling in ice-cold water, cold thoracic and peritoneal lavage, and use of chilled intravenous fluids and cooling blankets are less effective.
  • Continuous temperature monitoring with a rectal thermistor 
  • Fluid and electrolyte resuscitation
  • Diagnosis and treatment of complications like rhabdomyolysis and myocardial injury.

Other Options:

Option B: Although antipyretics have no role in controlling the convulsions in a child with febrile seizures, they are indicated in to control the fever in the child.

Option C: Antipyretics are indicated in the management of hyperpyrexia seen in CNS haemorrhage or trauma to reduce the core body temperature and prevent the effects of hypothermia on the brain.

Option D: Antipyretics do not treat viral infections but are indicated for symptomatic relief of fever and the associated myalgias and arthralgias that also occur due to peripheral prostaglandins.

questions.text: 'Picket-fence' fever is typically associated with?
questions.solution:
Picket-fence fever is associated with pyelonephritis.

Pyelonephritis refers to symptomatic infection of the renal parenchyma and patients with a classic triad of loin pain, fever and costovertebral angle tenderness. The fever is typically described as picket-fence fever which is characterized by high-spiking fever with minimal variation that resolves over 72 hours of therapy.

Uncomplicated and complicated UTI can clinically be well-distinguished by the presence of fever in the latter. Uncomplicated UTI is usually confined to the bladder and lacks systemic symptoms.  Patients with cystitis (option A) present with voiding symptoms such as dysuria, urgency, supra-pubic pain and hematuria but fever is not a common symptom.

Fever suggests complicated UTI where the infection may have spread beyond the bladder. Patients with prostatitis (option C) may have fever but the more classical presentation involves dysuria and frequency associated with pelvic or perineal pain. Catheter-associated UTI (option D) or UTI due to the presence of some foreign body (stones, stents etc) also cause complicated UTI and may have a more prolonged pattern of fever with a delayed response to therapy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient in an old-age home is being evaluated for fever. Which of the following sites would provide the most accurate temperature recording in the patient?
questions.solution:
Rectal temperature would provide the most accurate temperature recording in this patient.

Although oral, axillary and tympanic membrane temperature recording may be more convenient, they are less accurate than rectal temperature, which has been documented to detect fever in elderly patients with more sensitivity and specificity.

The rectal temperature is about 0.4°C (0.7°F)higher than oral temperatures, which may be lower to mouth breathing and rapid or shallow breathing. Eardrum reflectance thermometers are now commonly used for geriatric patients but yield variable recordings. Axillary temperature recording is confounded by factors like sweat, skin thickness etc and hence is not accurate.

Lower esophageal and pulmonary artery temperatures are most reflective of core body temperature but require invasive methods and hence are not applicable to the out-patient setting.

questions.text: A woman presents with a high fever, vomiting, and one episode of seizures. She appears confused. She is a known case of Graves' disease with medication non-compliance.  For the past few days, she has been feeling feverish and had a cough. On examination, she has warm, moist skin, and tremors. The cardiac monitor shows some arrhythmias. Which of the following is not part of the treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient who has Graves' disease and an acute infection, now presents with high-grade fever, vomiting, one episode of seizure, and confusion. This is suggestive of a thyroid storm or thyrotoxic crisis. Management will not include Liothyronine. The patient is already in a state of thyrotoxicosis, in such cases, the addition of the most active form of thyroid hormone will be detrimental.

L3/ Liothyronine has a rapid onset of action and is indicated only in conditions where rapid action is preferred like rare cases of myxedema coma.

A thyroid storm is a rare but severe life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism. It is an acute hypermetabolic state induced by the release of excessive thyroid hormones. Crisis can be due to surgical or medical causes.

Causes:

  • Thyroidectomy
  • Stress
  • Infection
  • Trauma
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Emergency surgery
  • Drugs like anticholinergics or antiadrenergic or NSAIDs or chemotherapy

Features: They present 12–24 hours after surgery, but can occur on the table also.

  • General: Hyperpyrexia (> 41°C), severe dehydration
  • Cardiovascular: Circulatory collapse, hypotension, palpitations, tachycardia, cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac failure
  • Respiratory: Tachypnoea, hyperventilation
  • GI symptoms: vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice.
  • Neurological symptoms: restlessness, irritability, delirium, tremor, convulsions, and coma 
  • Bailey’s symptom complex of thyroid storm is – insomnia, anorexia, diarrhoea, vomiting, sweating, emotional instability, fever, tachycardia, aggravated toxic features, multiorgan dysfunction.

Differential diagnoses are—malignant hyperpyrexia, septic shock, anxious status, cardiac disorders.

Investigations:

  • Raised T3, T4, suppressed TSH
  • Raised serum calcium
  • ECG and echocardiography show arrhythmias 
  • Raised total count
  • Altered liver function tests
  • Arterial blood gas (ABG) shows acid-base imbalance 

Treatment:

  • Supportive measures –
    • rehydration by proper fluid therapy, tepid sponging, cooling blankets
    • Antipyretics like a paracetamol IV infusion
    • Glucocorticoids (Hydrocortisone 500 mg IV or dexamethasone injections)
    • IV dextrose infusion as there is more metabolic demand
    • Correction of electrolytes
    • Treating cardiac arrhythmias in the ICU care with ventilator support.
    • Central line, CVP monitor, nasogastric tube, the urinary catheter should be placed.
  • Antiadrenergic drugs – Propranolol is used to reduce tachycardia and other adrenergic manifestations. It also reduces the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. If propranolol is contraindicated, atenolol or metoprolol can be used
  • Thionamides – propylthiouracil (PTU) or methimazole or carbimazole is used.
  • Iodide compounds – Lugol’s iodide or potassium iodide is given one hour after intake of thionamides. Potassium iodide inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis by Wolff- Chaikoff effect. Large doses of iodide inhibit organic binding of the iodide and hence decrease thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • Bile acid suppressants to prevent reabsorption of thyroid hormone from the gut – cholestyramine. Iodinated radiocontrast dyes like iopanoic acid is also beneficial. Lithium carbonate 300 mg 6th hourly is also useful.
  • Digitoxin, cardiac monitoring is crucial.
  • Treating specific causes 
  • Other measures—Hemodialysis, plasmapheresis, exchange transfusion, charcoal plasma perfusion are other methods used to control the storm.

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

Related Pearl: Radioiodine uptake of thyroid gland

Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scans are interpreted as follows:

  • High (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone. Therefore, there is increased hormone synthesis
  • Low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates:
    • Inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of the preformed hormone into the circulation
    • Extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone

questions.text: The image below shows changes in body temperature (red line) in response to the changes in the set point of the hypothalamic temperature controller (dotted blue line). At which point does the patient experience chills?
questions.solution:
The patient experiences chills at point 1 in the above image.

When the hypothalamic set point is raised suddenly, the actual body temperature is still at the normal level. The body tries to conserve heat and causes vasoconstriction and the patient feels cold. Then, the patient experiences chill and shivering until the actual body temperature reaches the setpoint.

Once the body temperature reaches the setpoint, the patient feels neither cold nor hot.

When factors such as toxins that caused the setpoint to rise are removed from the blood, the setpoint suddenly falls. This point is called a crisis or flush. At this point, the actual body temperature is still at a higher level. As a result, the patient feels hot, and there is vasodilation. The body loses heat by intense sweating.

questions.text: A farmer was diagnosed with brucellosis. Which of the following patterns of fever will be seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
Brucellosis is a bacterial zoonosis caused by Brucella sp which presents with undulant fever. It is referred to as undulant fever because of the rising and falling of fever like a wave (remittent fever). Patients may also have arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. CNS symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. 

Other options

Option A: Pel-Ebstein fever is seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma. It is characterized by fever lasting 3–10 days followed by afebrile periods of 3–10 days.

Option C: Relapsing fever is seen in infection with Borrelia recurrentis in which days of fever are followed by a several-day afebrile period and then relapse into additional days of fever. A similar picture is also seen in malaria.

Option D: Saddleback fever is seen in dengue.  Saddleback fever is defined as temperature >37.5°C  with defervescence of at least one day, followed by a second peak lasting at least one day.

questions.text: A confirmed case of which of the following viral haemorrhagic fevers was found in India?
questions.solution:
Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever has been found in India.

Four cases were first described in India in 2011 in the state of Gujarat. It is a severe form of viral hemorrhagic fever caused by negative sense ssRNA Nairovirus species. It is zoonotic in origin with Ixodes ticks as vectors with livestock as primary reservoirs. The outbreak was caused due to person-to-person transmission in a tertiary care hospital where the index patient (first identified case) was admitted.

questions.text:
Match the following types of fever with their respective temperature variations.
Type of fever Temperature variation
1. Persistent A. Temperature >38°C on multiple occasions; no localizing signs
2. Remittent B. Temperature elevated multiple times a day; touches baseline
3. Intermittent C. Temperature fluctuates <1°C during a day; always above baseline
4. PUO D. Temperature fluctuates >2°C during a day; always above baseline
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Type of fever Temperature variation
1. Persistent C. Temperature fluctuates <1°C during a day; always above baseline
2. Remittent D. Temperature fluctuates >2°C during a day; always above baseline
3. Intermittent B. Temperature elevated multiple times a day; touches baseline
4. PUO A. Temperature >38°C on multiple occasions; no localizing signs

 

A temperature of >99.9°F or >37.7°C defines a fever. Body temperature also has a diurnal and seasonal variation, being higher in the winters and late afternoons, and lower in the summers and mornings. Rectal temperature measurements are higher than the oral readings and the unadjusted tympanic membrane temperature measurements. 

While monitoring the temperature readings in in-patients at the hospital, the following types of patterns can be noticed:

  • Persistent fever is the one where the temperature remains above the baseline throughout the day and it doesn't fluctuate by >1°C during this time.
  • Remittent fever is the one where the temperature remains above the baseline throughout the day, but it fluctuates by >2°C during this time.
  • Intermittent/spiking fever is one where the temperature is above the baseline only on a few occasions throughout the day, but is normal at other times. 

There is an entity known as pyrexia of unknown origin (PUO). It has been defined as a temperature >38°C (101°F) on two occasions but without a certain diagnosis despite 1 week of inpatient evaluation. There are no localizing signs present to point to the origin of the fever. In developing countries, infections (such as tuberculosis) remain the most prominent cause of PUO. Other causes include autoimmune diseases (such as systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, vasculitis) and hematological and solid organ malignancies.

questions.text: A patient with a complex psychiatric history is on a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor. She visits her primary care physician with increasing depression. The physician adds a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Which of the following is she most likely to develop?

choices.text: Fever, rigidity, dilated pupils, and hyperreflexia
Fever, dystonia, rigidity and normal pupils
Fever, normotonia, dilated pupils and normal reflexes
Fever, rigidity, normal pupils and reduced bowel sounds

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of fever, rigidity, hyperreflexia, and dilated pupils are seen in the patient who is on a MAO inhibitor +  SSRI. It is due to the development of serotonin syndrome.

Serotonin syndrome occurs due to the concurrent administration of an SSRI with an MAO-inhibitor, L-tryptophan, or lithium, raising plasma serotonin concentrations to toxic levels. This serious and possibly fatal syndrome with the symptoms 

  • diarrhea, diaphoresis, flushing, mydriasis, salivation
  • restlessness
  • extreme agitation, hyperreflexia, and rapid fluctuations in vitals
  • myoclonus, hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, rigidity; and eventually
  • delirium, status epilepticus, cardiovascular collapse, and death. 

Treatment involves removing the offending agent and supportive care.
